messages.message:
Heyo, just to continue the conversation on prioritizing bugs and what that might look like :woman-bowing::skin-tone-2: here are the couple questions I mentioned if @prateek.tenkale @Weiming Wu or anyone else had more thoughts:
• What kinds of bugs are reaching customers and staying unresolved for months/year+ (blockers, edge cases)? What types of bugs do you think should be fixed before it reaches a customer or  asap?
• When do you have time to work on them?
I ask because I've noticed a lot of the time my lower priority bugs end up in backlog forever in favor of feature development, so I'm curious to identify the discrepancy between when we can take on ticks vs when people think we should, in case there are other changes we can make beyond better quality testing

In my case, many of these bugs honestly didn't even have tickets with priorities assigned to them. I had to compile the list myself and sync with @jack.robbins separately to get a better sense of the priority. Some of the issues solution engineers had flagged previously but we just never got around to addressing it for some reason

I don't think we realistically will be able to make much headway on it unless we make some rule where every engineer needs up a certain % of story points of their sprint towards addressing bug tickets
That and for features that are historically very buggy, there is a product-led initiative to improve it and it is given the same importance as a new feature is

I'm always trying to get feature work in, so that's why I don't tackle the bugs until way later...
Also these bugs were review related, and since Udit's gone, we don't have a domain expert anymore, so I'm scared to invest time into looking at it. It could end up being a multi day bug fix
We have Amplitude tracking now, so that should help us figure out which parts of the product people are using the most, and we can hopefully prioritize using that?
